row.name: East Melbourne community garden
row.what: Community garden for the East Melbourne Community Garden Group with 10 plots. Land is leased for $1 per year for 12 months (option to extend).

row.name: Yarra Park Children’s Centre school garden
Buncle Street community garden
row.what: 45 plots tucked in beside the North Melbourne Community Centre. Home to gardeners mostly from Central America, South America and China, the garden is a peaceful space where a love of growing is freely shared amongst the gardeners despite language barriers. Managed by Cultivating Community.
row.access: Must apply for a plot

row.name: Carlton community garden
row.what: The 530 Lygon Street Community Garden was rebuilt during 2012 with financial support provided by the Department of Human Services and philanthropic sources. The garden is specially designed to assist older residents.
row.access: Must apply for a plot

row.name: Lady Huntington Children’s Centre
row.what: 5 child height plots, used for kindergarten education program and for produce for the children's day menus.

row.name: Alfred Street community garden
row.what: 60 plots located at the base of the Alfred Street high rise block in North Melbourne, this garden feels very much like the tenants’ backyard. It was refurbished through our Garden Improvement program in 2012, with financial support provided by the Department of Human Services. The food grown in this garden reflects the cultural diversity of the local community, including many Vietnamese and African gardeners. Managed by Cultivating Community.

row.name: Kensington community garden
row.what: Provides 38-49 private plots for hire that are available to Kensington residents to grow herbs, vegetables and flowers. Run by YMCA. Does not conduct community development activities or provide education workshops.
row.access: Must apply. Plots allocated to 3031 residents only.
row.address_2: Corner Westbourne Road and Cornish Lane

row.name: Crown Street community garden
row.what: Located on a high-rise estate close to Melbourne showgrounds. Managed by Cultivating Community.

row.name: Docklands community garden
row.what: Docklands community garden has lemon and lime trees, a rosemary grove, vegetable patches, a communal BBQ, plus barrels for herbs and other edibles. Over winter, garden beds are open for all to dig as they please, and people are welcome to help develop the guiding principles and systems for a coordinated spring planting season. It's a great place for people to literally get their hands dirty and become green thumbs in a convivial community garden. Currently seeking members.

row.name: Kensington Primary School
row.what: Cooking & Gardening Program - Grades are rostered onto the cooking and gardening program every Wednesday morning. The program is run by a teacher and relies on parent volunteers to assist.

row.name: North Melbourne Sustainability community garden
row.what: 6 plots.

row.name: Neill Street community garden
row.what: Recently rebuilt in 2010 over 60 gardeners make use of this small space nestled in between the original Carlton towers and the new private/public development. This garden provides a great example of how much can be produced in a small space. A small pizza oven provides a resource for garden celebrations. Managed by Cultivating Community.

row.name: Flemington community garden
row.what: The Flemington Community garden was originally established in the early 1990’s. It underwent major renovation during 2005. Managed by Cultivating Community.

row.name: University of Melbourne community garden
row.what: Each week people get together to work on the garden, teach each other new things and, of course, eat the food grown.
row.who: Open to students, ex-students and locals to grow vegetables, fruit and herbs.
row.access: The best way to join the garden is to come to a working bee.

row.name: St Kilda Community Kitchen
row.what: The St Kilda Community Kitchen is a community-run weekly activity that is based on the idea that we all get stuck on cooking the same recipes day in, day out. But, while those recipes might be tired and boring to one person, they’re completely new and exciting to others! Each week people from backgrounds come together to have fun socialising and cooking, all the while expanding their cooking repertoire. With everybody pitching in their ideas and skills in this way, you don’t need to be an expert to join in the fun, since it’s really about enjoying the experience of cooking in a relaxed and friendly group setting. The St Kilda Community Kitchen uses food that is kindly provided by SecondBite.
row.enter_via: Enter off Bath St and look for the signs pointing to the Community Room, also known as the Pinaroo room.

row.name: Atherton Gardens Community Kitchen
row.what: The Atherton Gardens community kitchen aims to bring people together to access fresh food, learn how to prepare healthy, culturally diverse and affordable meals, and share food in a spirit of conviviality. Cultivating Community, with funding from the Fitzroy Housing Office, coordinates the management of the kitchen, supports and encourages a variety of groups to use the kitchen and also runs a weekly cooking program in the kitchen. The kitchen has a plot in the community garden for herbs and seasonal vegetables and composts all food scraps through the community garden.
row.who: The community kitchen is available to groups and individuals for food related events, workshops, activities and celebrations.
row.access: Contact Peta at Cultivating Community for more information on current programs and availability
row.address_1: Fitzroy Community Food Centre at Atherton Gardens Estate

row.name: From the Market to the Kitchen
row.what: This program is for people who would like to learn basic cooking skills like how to cook quick and healthy meals with limited equipment. Discover where local markers and affordable food outlets are, gain an accredited certificate in food handling, improve your nutrition knowledge, make new friends, receive one-one-one advice from the dietitians and get assistance setting up your kitchen at home.
row.who: This group is open to people who would like to socialise while improving their cooking skills and nutrition knowledge, especially those who have recently moved into housing and who have limited cooking facilities.
row.contact_person: Contact Susie at Central City Community Health Centre
row.access: First intake starts 30 May and second intake starts 22 August. Group runs for 6 weeks.
row.tram_routes: Tram: Route 57 (West Maribyrnong), Route 59 (Airport West), Route 19 (North Coburg) all travel along Elizabeth street and stop outside the Queen Victoria Market.
row.car_parking: Metered parking is located on the street and large car parks are available nearby.
row.bicycle_parking: Bike parking is available via bike parking hoops in the streets.
row.walking: Approximately a 10 minute walk from Melbourne’s central business district. Walk toward the Queen Victoria Market along Elizabeth Street.

row.name: Kitchen Skills, Port Melbourne Neighbourhood House
row.what: For 2 hours once a week, participants can learn to cook cheap practical meals, starting with the very basics (no experience needed). Each week participants prepare a meal together (a main course and dessert) with the chef, and then sit down to share the meal they have prepared. The class is small and relaxed with the main focus being on fun and having a good time.
row.access: Runs during the school term

row.name: Grow and Eat
row.what: This is a social cooking activity using produce from the Simply Living community garden.
row.who: General community, people on low incomes, people with disabilities and/or poor mental health
row.contact_person: Janet Hoare, South Port Uniting Church
row.access: 1st Wednesday of the month
row.tram_routes: Route 109, North Port station (stop 127), 4 minute walk along Raglan and Nott Sts (start towards Bay St)
row.bus_routes: Bus 238, 250, 253, corner Bay and Bridge Streets, 1 minute walk along Bridge St (follow Uniting Church sign)

row.name: Kitchen Mates
row.what: Invites people to meet new friends and cook and eat low affordable, healthy meals together in a supportive environment. Run by South Port Uniting Church.
row.who: General community, people on low incomes, people with disabilities and/or poor mental health
row.contact_person: Janet Hoare, South Port Uniting Church
row.access: Held fortnightly on Fridays. Bookings required.
row.cost: Participants decide what the group will cook at the next session and pay on a per serve basis (approximately $3 per serve).
row.tram_routes: Route 109, North Port station (stop 127), 4 minute walk along Raglan and Nott Sts (start towards Bay St)
row.bus_routes: Bus 238, 250, 253, corner Bay and Bridge St, 1 minute walk along Bridge St (follow Uniting Church sign)
row.address_2: Corner of Nott and Bridge Streets

row.name: Boyd Community Hub
row.what: Vegetable and herb planter boxes are located at the Boyd Community Hub in the public areas and in the fenced outdoor play space attached to the Boyd Playroom. People can come and help themselves while they visit the centre.
row.tram_routes: 1 - Stop 17 (Melbourne Recital Centre), Route 55 - Stop 114 (City Road/ Queensbridge Street) or route 112, stop 126 (City Road)
row.car_parking: On street metered parking: Check parking signs before leaving vehicle as conditions may change.

row.name: Community Herb Share Program
row.what: Save yourself from buying fresh herbs by becoming a member of the Herb Share Program at the Kensington Neighbourhood House. For two hours of your time plus $20 per year you can help yourself to fresh herbs as often as you like.
row.access: Become a member of the Herb Share Program. Express your interest on the website.
row.tram_routes: Route 57 (West Maribyrnong – city Elizabeth Street), stop 26.
row.nearest_train_station: Kensington Train Station is a 3 minute walk from the House. If arriving from the City, cross Bellair Street and walk up Wight Street. McCracken Street is at the top of the hill.
row.car_parking: All day parking is located on McCracken Street in front of the House. Two hour parking on surrounding streets.

row.name: Brunswick Unity Church Food Co-op
row.what: The co-op aims to reduce packaging and purchase organic and Australian grown foods. The co-op offers more than 50 dry food products for sale such as flours, sugars, nuts, dry pasta, lentils and tea and coffee.
row.access: Open 3rd Saturday of the month. Become a member simply by turning up and paying your membership fee of $1 per visit. You will need to bring empty containers and bottles. All members help out by participating on the roster twice a year, either setting up, packing up or serving.

row.name: Friends of the Earth Food Co-op and Cafe
row.what: Provides affordable, low packaged food including fruit and vegetable that are organic and grown/prepared locally. Bring your own bags/containers. Bring your own cup for take away tea and coffee. The café also offers cheap meals ranging from $10-12.50. Volunteers get a 15% discount off their shopping in the co-op. If you are interested in volunteering, visit the website.
row.access: You don't have to be a member to shop

row.name: Realfoods, RMIT Food Co-op
row.what: Seasonal, organic, locally grown fruit and vegetable boxes delivered to your door. Also provides cheap organic, vegetarian and vegan meals.
row.access: All orders must be in before 9.30am the day before your delivery day. To order, go to http://organicempire.com.au/shop/, select the RMIT Student Box from the list and enter the code RUSULOVESHEALTH for your subsidy.
row.address_1: RMIT University City Campus - Food Court, Building 8, Level 4

row.name: University of Melbourne Food Co-op
row.what: Offers a range of locally grown/organic goods for sale including beans, lentils, pasta, rice, flour, dried fruit, nuts, seeds, grains, tea, soy milk and spices and herbs. They also have local, organic fruit and vegetable boxes from Green Gully Organics.
row.who: Open to everyone, not just students. You don’t have to be a member or a volunteer to eat at the Melbourne University Food Co-op, however membership entitles you to 10% on everything. On top of that, volunteering 2 hours per week gets you a free meal and 20% off everything.
row.access: No membership required
row.cost: Fruit and vegetable boxes cost $30 or $20 if you are a member. Membership to the co-op costs $10 (unwaged) or $20 waged for the year.
row.tram_routes: Catch any Swanston St tram to the University tram stop and walk up to the Tin Alley entrance (Gate 1), 19 tram on Royal Parade to the Tin Alley entrance (Gate 14).

row.category: Food Delivery and Shopping Support Services
row.name: Local Organics
row.what: Local Organics is a Melbourne-based food hub created to give access to ethical food from sustainable, organic and biodynamic Victorian family farms. They buy directly from farmers each week to collect fresh seasonal produce. They provide mixed boxes, individual orders, wholesale, work as a collection point for farmer direct mixed boxes, and operate as a store in Brunswick East.
row.car_parking: Delivery costs $6.75 for most Melbourne suburbs.

row.category: Food Delivery and Shopping Support Services
row.name: Abbotsford Wooden Box
row.access: For a Tuesday delivery, you must order before Sunday 11.59pm. For a Thursday delivery, you must order before Tuesday 11.59pm. You must order before Sunday 11:59pm for a Wednesday delivery. Deliveries are made between 11am-7pm, Wednesdays.
row.cost: Prices for food boxes range from $28-78. Pick up free from one of our many Food Hosts located across Melbourne

row.category: Food Delivery and Shopping Support Services
row.name: CERES Fair Food
row.what: Organic food delivery service and online grocer, providing Melbourne with the freshest seasonal organic fruits, vegetables, and other organic groceries, all sourced from our network local farmers and artisans. They pay farmers a fair price for their sustainably grown food, delivering fair food boxes of certified organic fruits, vegetables and other groceries such as bread, free range eggs and bio-dynamic milk to households across Melbourne.
row.who: Services Carlton, Flemington and South Melbourne.
row.cost: From $50 for a small box = $50.00. Delivery = $6-9

row.category: Food Delivery and Shopping Support Services
row.name: Street Organics
row.what: Home Delivered Organic Fresh Produce service throughout Greater Melbourne and the Mornington Peninsula.
row.cost: Minimum order of $40. Organic seasonal produce boxes e.g. 5.5-6.5kg box is $55, delivery fee - $10

row.category: Food Delivery and Shopping Support Services
row.name: Organic Angels
row.what: Delivers organic produce directly to your door.
row.cost: Mixed fruit and vegetable boxes start from $43.50 plus delivery.

row.category: Food Delivery and Shopping Support Services
row.name: Organic Empire
row.what: Locally sourced from a farm in the Yarra Valley, they deliver organic foods, organic fruits, organic vegetables and organic groceries, sustainable and local foods to your home or office throughout Melbourne.
row.who: Open to everyone. Services metropolitan Melbourne.
row.cost: Minimum order of $45 excluding delivery charges.$8.95 flat rate per delivery in Metro Melbourne.

row.category: Food Delivery and Shopping Support Services
row.name: City of Melbourne’s home delivered meals support
row.what: Older adults in the municipality who are unable to prepare meals at home and who are eligible for the Home and Community Care (HACC) program can access City of Melbourne’s home delivered meal service. The service can cater for specific dietary needs and assistance with meal preparation is also available.
row.who: Clients need to be part of the Home and Community Care (HACC) program. Available for people who are unable to prepare meals at home, need support with transport.
row.access: Meals are delivered five days a week and weekend meals can be delivered on Fridays. Clients need to be part of the Home and Community Care (HACC) program.
row.cost: Average cost for a three course meal is around $6 to $10 for eligible clients.

row.category: Food Delivery and Shopping Support Services
row.name: City of Melbourne community transport program – support with grocery shopping
row.what: City of Melbourne’s community transport program is available for residents who have difficulty using public transport because of frailty, disability or isolation. A pre-booked transport service for shopping trips is available within municipal boundaries. Local shopping destinations include Queen Victoria Market, Footscray Market, Prahran Market, Barkley Square and ALDI.
row.access: This service is subject to eligibility and a fee.

row.name: Collingwood Children’s Farm - volunteer sessions
row.what: Keen gardeners or those who’d like to learn more about gardening can join in these volunteer sessions to learn more about land care and harvesting fruit and vegetables.
row.access: No need to book, just turn up on the day. It is compulsory for all volunteers to have a current Working with Children check. As a volunteer you may get one for free, you just need to pay for the photos. Forms can be obtained from the post office.

row.name: Gardening Veg Out
row.what: Veg Out is a gardening group for people who want to learn how to grow, harvest and prepare their own vegetables. At Veg Out you will learn: how to plan what to plant, gardening including weeding, watering, sowing seeds and transplanting seedlings, how to harvest vegetables and some cooking activities using the freshly picked vegetables. The program is run by Inner South Community Health Centre.
row.who: Open to everyone. People who want to garden and have limited access to gardening and people who would like to meet others who share an interest in gardening.
row.access: Open every 2nd Wednesday of the month. Group members can come to the garden at any time and water or weed.
row.address_2: corner Shakespeare Grove and Chaucer Street

row.name: Edible Gardening for Beginners - The Little Vege Patch Company
row.what: In this 2-hour workshop you will learn how to grow your own organic vegetables, take care of your gardens and how to make the most of small spaces. You will get simple and localised information and tips to grow a thriving garden in any space, get dirt between your fingers, with a hands-on interactive learning environment and receive an heirloom seed pack. The course is run by the Little Vege Patch Company, a Melbourne-based business dedicated to helping people grow food. They also run other food-related workshops such as preserving – check out their website.
row.access: To check out when the next workshop is, see the website.

row.name: Permablitz Melbourne
row.what: Permablitz is an informal gathering involving a day on which a group of at least two people come together to create or add to edible gardens. Permablitzes are free events, open to the public, with free workshops and shared food. If you come to three or so permablitzes, they can help organise one at your house. The permablitz network is based on reciprocal volunteer support.
row.who: Open to everyone. Skill level and physical capacity aren't problems at all. We especially welcome first time gardeners. Just come and contribute anyway you are able.
row.access: For upcoming events, see the website. Getting involved is easy. Go to the website and sign up to the Melbourne Permablitz Newsletter to stay in the loop about upcoming blitzes and courses. You'll get dates and addresses, and then you can just show up, or RSVP where asked.

row.name: Anglicare, Mission House
row.what: Small food parcels
row.who: Provides assistance to people living in public housing and rental properties with a Healthcare Card. Assistance may be given to those living in the following postcodes: 3000 (Melbourne), 3051 (North Melbourne), 3053 (Carlton), 3054 (Carlton North), 3065 (Fitzroy), 3066 (Collingwood), 3067 (Abbotsford), 3068 (Fitzroy North/Clifton Hill) and 3070 (Northcote).

row.name: Anglicare, The Lazarus Centre
row.what: Small food parcels
row.access: Once per week

row.name: St Mathew’s
row.what: Small food parcels and Bread
row.who: Open to anyone, particularly people who live in the local area. For your first visit, call and make an appointment.

row.name: St Mary’s House of Welcome
row.what: Small food parcels
row.who: Open to all adults aged over 18 years

row.name: Church of All Nations
row.what: Vouchers are available on a case by case basis. Tea, coffee, biscuits, newspapers and friendly welcome greet those waiting for assistance.
row.who: A healthcare card or Centrelink identification is required
row.access: No appointment necessary

row.name: Asylum Seeker Resource Centre (ASRC)
row.what: Food bank/pantry with perishable and non-perishable items available
row.who: Asylum seekers, refugees who are members of the ASRC
row.access: Once per week

row.name: Anglicare, St Mark’s Community Centre
row.what: Bread, fruit and vegetable
row.access: Once per week

row.name: Presbyterian and Scots Church Joint Mission, Flemington Mission
row.what: Non Perishables
row.access: Open 1st and 3rd of the Month. Once per week.

row.name: RISE
row.what: Dry foods as well as fruits and vegetables
row.access: Once per week
row.tram_routes: All Flinders and Colins St trams

row.name: Open House at St Peter’s and Paul’s Church
row.what: Small food parcels
row.who: Proof of residency South/Port Melbourne, Health Care Card/Pension Card
row.access: Once per month

row.name: Returned Servicemen’s League, Victorian branch
row.what: Food vouchers and other services
row.who: For former or serving members of the Australian Defence Force or Allied Forces and for their dependants who are experiencing financial hardship. For further information and to ascertain if you are eligible for assistance please contact using the details provided, evidence of financial hardship for assistance to be provided
row.contact_person: Jeff Jackson, Manager Pensions Advocacy and Welfare Support
row.access: Available via application form only
row.address_1: Returned and Services League of Australia, ANZAC House

row.name: Collingwood Cottage, St Joseph’s Church
row.what: Small food parcels
row.access: Must register after 9am for a number and collect parcel after 12pm

row.name: Positive Learning Centre, David Williams Fund
row.what: Food vouchers (and other emergency financial assistance) to people living with HIV who are experiencing financial hardship. Available via application form
row.who: Eligibility criteria: provide proof of HIV status, demonstrated receipt of Social Security Benefit or Pension, demonstrated financial hardship, resident of Victoria, provide a Centrelink income statement
row.access: Available via application form only

row.name: Positive Learning Centre, David Williams Fund
row.what: David Williams Fund application Form collection point only. Please refer to Positive Learning Centre, David Williams Fund for details
row.who: David Williams Fund application Form collection point only. Please refer to Positive Learning Centre, David Williams Fund for details
row.address_1: Victorian AIDS Council/Gay Men's Health Centre

row.name: Positive Learning Centre, David Williams Fund
row.what: David Williams Fund application Form collection point only. Please refer to Positive Learning Centre, David Williams Fund for details
row.who: David Williams Fund application Form collection point only. Please refer to Positive Learning Centre, David Williams Fund for details

row.name: Positive Learning Centre, David Williams Fund
row.what: David Williams Fund application Form collection point only. Please refer to Positive Learning Centre, David Williams Fund for details
row.who: David Williams Fund application Form collection point only. Please refer to Positive Learning Centre, David Williams Fund for details
row.address_1: HIV Coordinator, The Royal Melbourne Hospital

row.name: Salvation Army (Project 614). The Marketplace
row.what: A supermarket style food pantry which offers a wide selection of food and other necessities to those who need them most.

row.name: Christ Church
row.what: Six items of canned food for emergency only
row.access: One per person, Once per month
row.address_2: Cnr Punt Rd and Toorak Rd

row.name: Yarra Urban Harvest Swapmeet
row.what: A monthly food swap for any excess home grown herbs, fruits and vegetables, favourite garden produce recipes, seeds, cuttings, seedlings, preserves, jams and inspirations for edible neighbourhoods.
row.access: Open 1st Saturday of the month

row.name: Urban Orchard Food Swap
row.what: The CERES Urban Orchard Project is a collection of folk from over 200 households across the inner northern suburbs of Melbourne who swap and share excess produce from their backyard gardens. Those with produce to swap, gather every Saturday at the CERES Organic Market. Members of the project leave their excess fruit, vegetables, herbs etc on the swap table and take produce others have dropped off.
row.who: Open to everyone, even if nothing to give.
row.access: No membership required. If you are interested, come down one Saturday morning to the CERES Organic Market and visit their stall.
row.tram_routes: 96 to the end of the line (intersection of Blyth and Nicholson Streets), 5 minute walk.
row.bus_routes: 503 Essendon to East Brunswick, get off at the Lee Street stop.
row.car_parking: Parking is available but it can be busy on market days.
row.bicycle_parking: Merri Creek bike path (exit at fate closest to Blyth Street/Arthurton Road bridge).

row.name: Hare Krishna Temple, Crossways
row.what: All you can eat vegetarian, vegan and gluten free meals
row.who: Students, the elderly and other concession card holders
row.cost: All you can eat for $7.50 ($5.50 concession and 50 cents for takeaway)

row.name: Anglicare, The Lazarus Centre
row.access: BBQ lunch every Friday

row.sub_category: Breakfast / Lunch / Morning tea / Afternoon tea
row.name: St Mary’s House of Welcome
row.what: Breakfast, morning tea, lunch and afternoon tea
row.who: Open to all adults aged over 18 years
row.monday: Breakfast: 8:45am - 9:15am, Morning Tea: 10:30am, Lunch: 12:00pm - 12:30pm, Afternoon Tea: 3:00pm
row.tuesday: Breakfast: 8:45am - 9:15am, Morning Tea: 10:30am, Lunch: 12:00pm - 12:30pm, Afternoon Tea: 3:00pm
row.thursday: Breakfast: 8:45am - 9:15am, Morning Tea: 10:30am, Lunch: 12:00pm - 12:30pm, Afternoon Tea: 3:00pm
row.friday: Breakfast: 8:45am - 9:15am, Morning Tea: 10:30am, Lunch: 12:00pm - 12:30pm, Afternoon Tea: 3:00pm
row.cost: Breakfast: Free or by donation, Morning and Afternoon Tea: Free, Lunch: $2

row.name: Baptist Church
row.what: Dinner
row.access: Held fortnightly

row.name: Credo Café
row.what: Lunch
row.access: Visit as often as you would like.

row.name: Senior Citizen Centres, Food with Friends
row.what: Multicultural lunches: three course meals from different cuisines for older adults in the City of Melbourne’s Senior Citizen Centres.
row.access: Open 1st and 3rd Thursday of the month. Bookings are essential. Contact the centres directly.

row.name: Church of All Nations
row.what: Lunch
row.access: BBQ lunch every 2nd Sunday of the month

row.name: Senior Citizen Centres, Food with Friends
row.what: Multicultural lunches: three course meals from different cuisines for older adults in the City of Melbourne’s Senior Citizen Centres.
row.access: Open 2nd and 4th Wednesday of the month, Bookings are essential. Contact the centres directly.

row.name: Hare Krishna Temple, Food For Life
Carlton Neighbourhood Learning Centre
row.what: Community lunch for people with mild disabilities.
row.access: Referrals and assessment required to access the program, can be a self-referral
row.bicycle_parking: Princes Street (close to Canning Street bicycle route)

row.name: Prahran Mission Café, Prahran City Mission
row.what: Breakfast and lunch.
row.access: Need to show concession card

row.name: The Olive Way
row.what: Snacks, sandwiches and tea/coffee
row.who: General community but with a focus on people on low incomes, people with disabilities and/or poor mental health

row.name: Asylum Seeker Resource Centre (ASRC)
row.what: Hot lunches. Meals are carefully planned to ensure nutrition and a well-balanced diet
row.who: Asylum seekers, refugees who are members of the ASRC

row.name: Anglicare, St Mark's Church Community Centre
row.what: Lunch

row.name: Collingwood Neighbourhood House, Men's Breakfast
row.what: Breakfast
row.access: During school term

row.name: Collingwood Neighbourhood House, Mother's Kitchen
row.what: Vegetarian lunches which usually include rice, a main vegetable dish, fried noodles or pasta, spring rolls or dumplings, salad, fruit and dessert. The cultural lunch is often Vietnamese inspired.
row.access: Vegetarian lunch 1st Saturday of the month, cultural lunch every Tuesday. No criteria for attendance, just come along

row.name: Open Table
row.what: Open Table is a not-for-profit food redistribution project that uses surplus food to create wholesome community feasts every month, bringing together people from all walks of life.
row.access: 4th Sunday of the month

row.name: Ozanam Community Centre
row.access: No documentation required. Drop in centre, referral not required.

row.name: Open Door, Seventh Day Adventist Church
row.what: Dinner

row.name: Friends of the Earth Food Café
row.what: Café offers tea/coffee, cakes and a hot meal of the day using food from their coop.

row.name: Realfoods Café, RMIT
row.what: The Realfoods Café is a student-run social enterprise which provides cheap organic, vegetarian and vegan meals
row.access: Only open during the university semester
row.address_1: RMIT University City Campus - Food Court, Building 8, Level 4

row.name: Open House at St Peters and Pauls
row.what: Breakfast, BBQ lunch, dinner and tea/coffee
row.who: Proof of residency South/Port Melbourne, Health Care Card/Pension Card

row.name: Open Table
row.what: Open Table is a not-for-profit food redistribution project that uses surplus food to create wholesome community feasts every month, bringing together people from all walks of life.
row.access: 1st Sunday of the month

row.name: The Kitchen
row.what: Continental style breakfasts and the occasional cooked breakfast and lunch. Includes two courses with the main course generally including meat. Tea and coffee facilities also provided.
row.who: Main target group is homeless people. Restricted to those over 18 years of age.
row.bicycle_parking: Get onto the Capital City Trail under City Link and turn off at Macaulay Station

row.name: Matthew Talbot Fitzroy Soup Van
row.what: Sandwiches, sausage rolls, meat pies, pasties, tea/coffee and cordial
row.access: Times are approximate

row.name: Carlton Neighbourhood Learning Centre
row.what: Morning tea for Seniors at the Carlton Housing Estate.
row.who: Seniors at the Carlton Housing Estate
row.access: Referrals and assessment required to access the program, can be a self-referral

row.name: The Centre
row.what: Drop in morning teas, nutrition information is also provided
row.access: 1st Tuesday of the month.

row.name: Senior Citizen Centres, Food with Friends
row.what: Multicultural lunches: three course meals from different cuisines for older adults in the City of Melbourne’s Senior Citizen Centres.
row.access: Open 2nd and 4th Friday of the month.

row.name: Salvation Army (Project 614), The Couch International Student Centre
row.what: Dinner. Also provides food through their Marketplace.

row.name: Salvation Army (Project 614), Hamodava Café
row.what: Breakfast and lunch. Also provides food through their Marketplace.

row.name: Missionaries of Charity, Men
row.what: Dinner

row.sub_category: Breakfast / Lunch / Morning tea / Afternoon tea
row.name: Coolibah Centre, Brotherhood of St Laurence
row.monday: Breakfast: 8.30am - 9.00am, Morning Tea: 10.00am, Lunch: 12.00pm, Afternoon Tea: 1.30pm
row.tuesday: Breakfast: 8.30am - 9.00am, Morning Tea: 10.00am, Lunch: 12.00pm, Afternoon Tea: 1.30pm
row.wednesday: Breakfast: 8.30am - 9.00am, Morning Tea: 10.00am, Lunch: 12.00pm, Afternoon Tea: 1.30pm
row.thursday: Breakfast: 8.30am - 9.00am, Morning Tea: 10.00am, Lunch: 12.00pm, Afternoon Tea: 1.30pm
row.friday: Breakfast: 8.30am - 9.00am, Morning Tea: 10.00am, Lunch: 12.00pm, Afternoon Tea: 1.30pm
row.access: Need to be a member, bookings are essential.
row.cost: Breakfast: $1, Morning Tea: Free, Lunch: $3 members or $7 non-members, Afternoon Tea: 20 cents
row.address_1: Coolibah Centre, Brotherhood of St Laurence

row.name: The Living Room
row.what: Offers snack foods in its drop in areas, with food ranging from bread, fresh fruit, sandwiches and tea/coffee
row.access: Drop in between 1-4pm, all other times by appointment.

row.name: Meals at the Bridge
row.what: Pop-up Café that offers a three-course nutritious, home cooked meal
row.who: Aimed at people who are homeless, marginalised, socially disadvantaged

row.name: Sacred Heart Mission
row.what: Breakfast and lunch
row.who: Open to everyone, particularly people who are homeless, socially disadvantaged and isolated

row.name: Kensington Neighbourhood House, Social Lunch and Bingo
row.what: Two-course meal and bingo in the company of a friendly social group.
row.access: Bookings are essential
row.car_parking: All day parking is located on McCracken Street in front of the House. Two hour parking can be found on surrounding streets

row.name: St Silas Sunday Suppers
row.what: Two course dinner

row.access: BBQ dinner on Friday nights

row.name: Open Table
row.what: Open Table is a not-for-profit food redistribution project that uses surplus food to create wholesome community feasts every month, bringing together people from all walks of life.
row.access: 3rd Sunday of the month
row.address_1: Fitzroy Community Kitchen in Atherton Gardens

row.name: Recycled Food Network
row.what: Recycled Food Network recycles leftover food from cafés around the central city and redistributes to those less fortunate.

row.name: Café Meals - Homeless
row.what: Subsidised meals for people experiencing homelessness. Members can get a meal to the value of $10 but only pay $2 towards the cost. You can choose breakfast, lunch or dinner.
row.who: People living in the City of Melbourne who are homeless or sleeping rough and who have trouble cooking for themselves or buying healthy meals. Program membership is required.
row.access: One meal a day, every day of the week. Program membership required. Show your membership card at participating Café's to get the offer

row.name: Rosie’s Bus

row.name: University of Melbourne Food Co-op
row.what: Organic, vegan and gluten free hot lunches in a diverse range of dishes including sweets and a range of tea.
row.who: Open to everyone, not just students. You don’t have to be a member or a volunteer to eat at the Melbourne University Food Co-op, however membership entitles you to 10% on everything. On top of that, volunteering 2 hours per week gets you a free meal and 20% off everything.

row.name: Collingwood Children’s Farm Farmers’ Market
row.access: Open 2nd Saturday of the month
row.cost: $2.00 donation per adult, children are free to enter

row.name: Gasworks Farmers’ Market
row.access: Open every 3rd Saturday of the month

row.name: Fitzroy Street Farmers’ Market
row.access: Open 4th Saturday of the month

row.name: The Veg Out St Kilda Farmers’ Market
row.access: Open 1st Saturday of the month

row.name: Queen Victoria Market
row.tram_routes: Routes 57, 58 and 19. Or take the free City Circle tram. Get off at the corner of La Trobe and Elizabeth Streets.
row.nearest_train_station: Within walking distance of Melbourne Central Station (Elizabeth Street exit, head north) and Flagstaff Station (north along William Street).
row.bus_routes: The Melbourne Visitor Shuttle goes to the Market for $5! Get off at stop 8.
row.car_parking: Free parking is available with entry and exit between 6am to 10am Sunday to Friday and from 6am to 8am on Saturday.
row.bicycle_parking: There is free bike parking in and around the Market. Major bike lanes leading to the Market run along Royal Parade and Victoria Street.
row.address_2: Corner of Victoria and Elizabeth Streets

row.name: Carlton Farmers’ Market
row.access: Open every 1st and 3rd Saturday of the month
row.tram_routes: Route 1 or 8- Stop 112 Elgin Street/Lygon Street, Route 1 or 8- Stop 113 Lytton Street/Lygon St
row.bus_routes: Route 250 or 251 - Stop 659 Pitt Street/Rathdowne Street, Route 250 or 251- Stop 349 Kay Street/Rathdowne Street
row.car_parking: Street Parking Available on surrounding Palmerston, Drummond, Rathdowne and Lygon Streets

row.name: CERES Organic Market
row.cost: There is no entry cost to CERES market, but you can make a gold coin donation if you wish.

row.name: Gleadell Street Fresh Food Market
row.public_holidays: Closed on public holidays that fall on a Saturday
row.tram_routes: 48 (North Balwyn – Victoria Harbour, via Collins Street) or 75 (Vermont South – City, via Flinders Street) and disembark at Stop 19 – Richmond Town Hall.

row.name: Slow Food Farmers’ Market
row.access: Open every 4th Saturday of the month
row.cost: $2 donation per adult, free for children

row.name: CoHealth Community Health Centre - Doutta Galla
row.what: Nutrition and dietitian services to help users to develop self-management skills around food budgeting, purchasing, preparation and cooking.
row.who: People experiencing disadvantage in the City of Melbourne
row.bus_routes: 402 Footscray to East Melbourne - Stops at Gower Street / Macaulay Road

row.name: CoHealth Community Health Centre - Central City
row.what: Nutrition and dietitian services to help users to develop self-management skills around food budgeting, purchasing, preparation and cooking.
row.who: People experiencing disadvantage in the City of Melbourne
row.access: Book an appointment between 10am to 4pm Mon to Fri or drop in Fridays between 1pm and 4pm
